title: How professionals can do business smarter – with support from HSBC Bank
text:
HSBC Bank Canada is dedicated to the success of small businesses. In fact, it’s so committed to their success that it provides dedicated small business relationship managers (BRMs) to each of its clients. BRMs are the first point of contact for business clients and provide both business guidance and tailored financial solutions on a one-to-one basis.

One client group at HSBC that benefits considerably from BRM support is the professional services sector – doctors, lawyers, accountants, veterinarians, architects, engineers and others who operate businesses built around their own professional services.

For Jonny Minh Huynh, a BRM with HSBC Bank Canada in Surrey, BC, serving professionals means developing a thorough understanding of their business.

Clients “can reach me directly and I’ll be their point of contact,” says Business Relationship Manager Ankita Singh. “For a doctor or other professional, that speed is critical.”

“I want to know why they got into the business,” he says. “They may want to remain a small office or have an appetite to expand. HSBC has a slate of products and services available to all small businesses, and as a BRM I provide value by directing them to the products and services most relevant to them. It’s like building a house. I want to make sure that they begin by choosing the accounts that make sense for the business and then we can carefully build on that foundation.”

Professionals with small offices, for example, often begin by operating their businesses from a personal bank account. That’s something HSBC BRMs are quick to correct, ensuring that personal and professional accounts are separated both for business and tax purposes. They’re encouraged to set up purpose-driven accounts, for example a chequing account where they set aside the GST or HST they collect, so there’s no problem making quarterly or annual payments. Different types of HSBC accounts are clearly delineated and offer fully transparent fee structures that help business owners make informed choices. Plus, the HSBC Unlimited Chequing account offers no monthly fees* to new business clients until December 31, 2019.

“However, for professional services clients, their business is often still very closely tied to their personal finances,” says Nicole Whyte, BRM with HSBC Bank Canada in Toronto. “They need and want to have everything integrated seamlessly. Using HSBCs online dashboard feature, even when their accounts are separated, they can see all of their personal and business accounts side by side.”

Professionals generally work extremely long hours, so doubling as the business manager of their company only adds to a heavy workload.

“Often, banking is their last priority,” says Ankita Singh, BRM with HSBC Bank Canada in Edmonton. “They often have no time to come into the branch, but I’m available to them, whether through text, phone, video conference or email. They don’t have to reach me through a call centre. They reach me directly and I will be their first point of contact. For a doctor or other professional, that speed is critical.”

HSBC’s online and phone banking services are also available to professionals 24/7. In addition, HSBC Bank Canada provides them with free access to cloud-based Sage applications that seamlessly integrate their bank accounts with the accounting package.

For professionals working a sole proprietors or unincorporated businesses, Huynh has suggested they speak to a corporate accountant about the advantages of establishing a professional corporation, a business entity that expands the range of tax advantages available to them.

HSBC can also offer a wide range of credit products that can help a professional services business to grow, from business credit cards to low-interest lines of credit, TFSA-secured loans, installment loans and personal and commercial mortgages.

“It’s important to match the purpose with the loan product,” says Huynh. “If a veterinarian wants to invest in an MRI unit so that the business no longer has to outsource that service, we want to fully understand their needs and how it will improve the business before structuring that loan.”

Some professional services businesses continue to grow, even beyond the scope of a BRM. HSBC’s commercial banking division can help them meet the more complex needs of a larger business, such as more intricate loan facilities, more complex payroll systems and accounts offering additional features.

“As a BRM dedicated to my professional services clients, it begins with having a great conversation,” says Huynh. “But it also means continuing that conversation throughout their relationship with HSBC, while providing them with the support that allows them to concentrate on what they do best.”

*Terms and conditions apply.

description: HSBC business relationship managers share their insights and advice for professionals
